instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: This board has one issue in that it can't get <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> because the pad is blown off on the enable line leading to <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> to make <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. See picture. Does anyone have any novel way of dealing with this type of thing? I need to get 3.3V to pin 10 but there's nothing I can tap in to. All I have is the 5V (then 20V) USB power line. I was thinking about trying to throw a couple resistors on there for a voltage divider but the problem is the line goes from 5V up to 20V so the voltage would be way to high on the enable once it bumps to 20V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> comes out from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and has 4-5V level.
Try to get it from <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: That's perfect, thanks. Didn't see that voltage line there. Turns on fine now. Thanks.
